newsitem.title: USA: New tests measure AIDS level in tonsils.
newsitem.headline: New tests measure AIDS level in tonsils.

text.p: A new way of measuring the AIDS virus in immune system cells in the tonsils will help researchers and doctors monitor AIDS patients and evaluate therapies, researchers said on Thursday.
A report on the new testing methods developed by University of Minnesota microbiologist Ashley Haase and his colleagues appears on Friday in the journal Science.

Other tests count the viral load in the bloodstream or count certain types of white blood cells that indicate how advanced AIDS is in a patient. But the new approach measures viral particles in two types of cells in lymphoid tissue -- on the surface of the cells that "store" the virus and inside the cells that make new virus particles.
Both of those cells can be reached through simple tissue collections from the tonsils.

The measurements combine several techniques already in use in other aspects of AIDS treatment and research. But by monitoring lymphoid cells doctors should get a better picture of what is happening during a patient's infection, not just in the bloodstream.

Scientists know that new combinations of anti-AIDS drugs can reduce the virus to undetectable levels in the bloodstream but they need to know more about whether there is a residue of virus in lymphoid cells and whether HIV can come back again.
Those questions are important in developing better treatments and in figuring out how best to use the drugs that are now available.
"We now have baselines to ask how effectively a therapy is working," Haase said in a statement released by the university. "This will tell us how to design and assess treatments."
Haase was out of the country and unavailable for further comment on Thursday.
